title: Crypto dictionary
body:
***[Read it in portuguese](https://mirror.xyz/0x07121d1002B35011B4118751bf6Dca5AC282915E/Sh04-WuqtmVdnNooEeVLkMRdTNwm4U8FtsQ_qUca-vw)***

Bitico appeared in 2009, but it was the beginning of the end. To help you understand a bit more about these terms and interact with the cryptoassets universe, we have prepared a complete dictionary of all the most commonly used slang in this medium.

kgujykfvugckythc,kn 

***A***

**Addy**

Address of a cryptocurrency wallet.

**Altcoin**

Term for alternative currencies to Bitcoin. Example: Eth, Litecoin, Dogecoin, Dash, Aioz, etc.

**ABC**

Acronym for anti-money laundering, in Portuguese: anti-money laundering. These are techniques to prevent money laundering, such as receiving money only through a bank transfer and the account holder itself, as Brazilian exchanges already do.

**Ask price**

This is the minimum price at which someone is willing to sell their asset.

**ASIC**

Application-specific integrated circuit acronym, in Portuguese: application-specific integrated circuits. Chip designed specifically for a particular task, e.g. in the case of Bitcoin, ASICs were designed to process a SHA -256 hash and mine Bitcoins.

**ATH**

The highest price ever reached by a particular cryptocurrency.

**Active**

Refers to a person's assets. For example, if there is $5,000.00 in a bank account, these are the assets in that bank account. In the case of cryptocurrencies, "Digital Assets" or "Crypto Assets".

**ATM**

ATM or in Portuguese: electronic box. where users can buy and sell Bitcoin using physical cash or debit cards. They are available in Brazil around the world, including some cities 

![Metamask wallet, arrow to reference the address.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KAZsRH_1E0HrxwBTBwrEI.png?height=726&width=1280)

***B***

**Ballast**

It is an asset that aims to provide a guarantee, i.e. it combines an initially worthless asset with something that has an implicit value. Today there are assets backed by BTC, DOLLAR, REAL, etc.

**Bear**

From the English, "Bear." The "Bear" is an investor who believes that the price of a cryptocurrency can fall at any moment. Thus, the Bear sells his assets before they depreciate too much. When we say that a market is "Bearish", it means that there are more sell orders than buy orders at that moment.

**Bearish**

This is an aggressive top-down chart behavior (characterized by a sharp decline and a short rally).

**bitcoin**

Starts with a lowercase letter and represents the monetary unit of the Bitcoin protocol.

**Bitcoin**

Starts with a capital letter and represents the protocol developed by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**Block Explorer**

Also known as a blockchain browser, this is a website or computer program that allows you to view transactions, addresses, blocks, and all the information of a blockchain and a particular cryptocurrency.

**Blockchain**

Blockchain, also known as trust protocol, is a distributed ledger technology that aims at decentralization as a security measure. It is considered Bitcoin's most important technological innovation as it is the proof of all transactions on the network. It records and stores all transactions in Bitcoin's history.

**Blockchain.info**

Company that offers a wallet service and a block explorer, confused with the Bitcoin blockchain.

**BTC**

Abbreviation for the currency unit of Bitcoin.

**Bull**

Means "Taurus" in English and is exactly the opposite of "Bear". The bull is the investor who believes in the cryptocurrency price trend. He bets on buying the currency at a low price to make a profit when the value rises.

**bullish**

It is an aggressive bottom-up chart behavior (characterized by a sharp rise and a short fall). It is also used to signal optimism for the market.

![Bulls vs Bears.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/K3PMkhgFCF2nLfjJjWA-9.png?height=1080&width=1080)

***C***

**Candlestick**

Candlestick is a graphical representation of the price of an asset. It allows to see the opening, high, low and closing prices within a time frame in the chart.

**Confirmation time**

Confirmation time is the time that elapses between a transaction being sent to the network and it being recorded in a block. Basically, it is the time a user has to wait before his transaction is confirmed on the network.

**Cold Storage**

A way to store cryptocurrencies offline, using paper, metal, or another alternative that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored or moved.

**Crypto**

Cryptography is a set of encryptions used to protect information in a way that only the sender and receiver can understand. It is used throughout the blockchain ecosystem and today by some companies like Facebook.

**Cryptocurrency**

Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies such as Bitcoin, Litecoin, Ethereum and many others that use cryptography for various purposes. Among other things, to ensure that all transactions are 100% secure.

**Custody**

To have control and ownership of assets. Having a wallet or assets in custody can also mean that your keys remain private and confidential.

**cypherpunk**

Cypherpunk is a community of online privacy and anonymity advocates. Their motto is: cypherpunks write code. They believe that those who want to protect their privacy should do it themselves instead of waiting for others to do it for them.

***D***

**Daytrader**

Investor who makes daily moves by buying and selling assets.

**Dump**

Sudden drop in the prices of cryptocurrencies.

**Dust transaction**

Transaction involving a small amount of bitcoins with little financial value, but which takes up space on the blockchain.

***E***

**ETH**

Ticker symbol of the cryptocurrency Ethereum.

**Escrow account**

Term used to describe the holding of funds in the possession of a third party to protect oneself during an operation.

**Ether**
Ethereum currency unit used to pay your blockchain fees.

**Ethereum**
Ethereum is a blockchain that permits the programming of decentralized applications, smart contracts and transactions of the cryptocurrency Ether and different tokens, as well as the creation of NFT collections and decentralized programs.

**Exchange**

Local, centralized, or decentralized exchange between cryptocurrencies and other assets, for example, exchanging dollars for bitcoin. Bitcoin exchanges are used to exchange bitcoin for FIAT coins or other cryptocurrencies.

***F***

**Faucet**

Websites that offer rewards in cryptocurrency for clicking ads or performing small tasks. Here is how: Answer a survey, provide your data, etc.

**Fee**

Fees paid on a transaction, for example: conversions, transfers and withdrawals.

**Fiat**

Conventional money (fiduciary money), i.e. money that is not a cryptocurrency, such as euros, reals, dollars, etc.

**FOMO**

Fear of missing out or fear of missing out on a profitable opportunity.

**Fork**

Updates to the cryptocurrency codes of coins, called a fork. A new coin that emerges from another, such as Bitcoin Dash, which is a fork of Bitcoin.

**Full Node**

It is the program that contains the consensus rules of the Bitcoin network and a full copy of the blockchain. Not every full node is a miner, but every miner is a full node.

***G***

**Gas**

The term gas refers to a pricing mechanism on the Ethereum network. It calculates the fees for executing a transaction or a smart contract operation.

**Genesis Block**

The first block of Bitcoin, created by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**GPU**

Graphical Processing Unit. Chip for processing complex mathematical calculations required for running games and software that require a lot of graphics resources.

***H***

**Halving**

Bitcoin halving is the emissions reduction that occurs every 4 years, as defined in the code.

**Hash**

An algorithm used by the Bitcoin protocol and other cryptocurrencies to convert a large amount of information into a fixed-length hexadecimal string of numbers.

**Hash Rate**

Number of hashes processed by a miner in a given period of time.

**HOLD**

In Portuguese, it means "to hold", i.e. we hold the asset even in the event of a significant devaluation, thinking about future valuations.

**Hot wallet**

It is a cryptocurrency wallet that is online and connected to the Internet. Like Metamask, Binance wallet, Trust wallet, Phantom and many others.

**Hype**

A term that indicates that something is the trend of the moment. For example, "NFTs are in an absurd hype".

***I***

**ICO**

Initial Coin Offering is a system for raising funds for a startup or company. Usually they come up with "revolutionary or unique ideas" that are applied on a blockchain.

**IDO**

Initial Dex Offering, A IDO is a crypto token offering conducted on a decentralized exchange (DEX).

**INPUT**

Origin address of a bitcoin transaction. A single transaction can have multiple origin addresses.

***K***

***Kilohashes/second - kH/s***

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in thousands of hashes.

***KYC***

Know your customer, in Portuguese. These are guidelines that government institutions impose on companies to find out who they are doing business with, i.e. they have data and documents of their customers.

***L***

**Ledger**

The ledger is a shared record of information, like a bank cash book, a book where all financial transactions in a bank are recorded, the ledger would be a place where transactions of cryptocurrencies running on the blockchain are recorded. . Today, it is also a wallet that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored without an internet connection.

**Liquidity**

It is the ability to buy or sell an asset easily, even in large quantities.

![Ledger used to store private keys securely.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eqe_0q0uws5zc_0jzyNZl.png?height=438&width=500)

***M***

**Malleability**

Ability to change uncommitted transactions without invalidating them.

**Manufacturer**

Maker is a term used when you place an order and it is not immediately traded. The order stays on the order book waiting for someone else to send a counter order so it can be executed.

**Marketcap**

The famous market cap. Amount of cryptocurrency circulating X crypto price.

**Megahashes/sec - MH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in millions of hashes.

**MicroBit - uBTC**

One millionth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.000001 BTC.

**MilliBit - mBTC**

One thousandth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.001 BTC.

**Mining**

This is the process of performing mathematical calculations. When a computer performs these cryptographic calculations, it receives a reward, X Bitcoin. We say that it mines and creates more Bitcoin.

**Mixer**

Service that encrypts the input and output of transactions to maintain privacy and reduce traceability.

***N***

**Node**

Device connected to the Bitcoin network that uses a computer program to forward transactions to other nodes, creating a decentralized network.

***O***

**Order:**

Market order that executes the purchase regardless of the price.

STOP -LIMIT orde - You choose a price and tell the system: "When the currency reaches X dollars, place an order LIMIT for Y dollars".

**Output**

Destination address for a bitcoin transaction. It is possible for a transaction to have multiple outputs.

***P***

**P2P**

P2P (Peer-to-Peer). Bitcoin was designed as a peer-to-peer system, meaning it does not need intermediaries, such as central banks, to broker a transaction between two people. In the market, this term is used to describe the trading of cryptocurrencies between two parties without the need for an exchange.

**Paper wallet**

It is considered a very safe way to store your cryptocurrencies, as they are not exposed to much risk precisely because they are offline. Since you do not need access to the Internet, it's basically a piece of paper that contains your private and public keys.

**Phishing**

In phishing, the user clicks on or downloads a fake file to steal information. Due to the popularity of cryptocurrencies, fake emails, files that change the victim's router settings or Google ads are spread more and more often to make the site appear first.

**Pool**

A collection of miners who join together to mine a block, and then divide the rewards among themselves. Mining pools are a great way to increase the probability of success as the difficulty increases.

**PoW**

It is the proof that a transaction has been validated and is legitimate. Using a mathematical function (SHA -256), transactions are encrypted and sent to the network where miners compete to decrypt them.

**Profit**

When we buy/ sell crypto and make profits.

**Pump**

When the price of a currency goes up.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3yfkb1zB1zKx5CtrUtCRZ.png?height=576&width=1024)

***R***

**Rekt**

The correct term would be "Wrecked", which means "ruined". It is the investor who has lost everything and ruined his equity when the price falls.

**ROI**

The return on an investment.

***s***

**Satoshi**

Smallest part of a Bitcoin = 0.00000001 BTC. If someone says they have 10 Satoshis, it means they have 0.00000010 BTC.

**Satoshi Nakamoto**

The name of the alleged inventor of Bitcoin.

**Scam**

Scams and frauds that are very common in cryptocurrency projects.

**ScamCoin**

Altcoin created with the purpose of defrauding users and enriching creators.

**SEPA**

Single European Payments Area, Portuguese, Single European Payments Area, is an integrated payment system between the countries of the Eurozone that allows the transfer of funds between banks and different countries. The transfer process is similar to the TED /DOC that we have in Brazil, but in the case of SEPA it includes all countries that use the euro.

**SHA-256**

Hash-like mathematical function used in Bitcoin in various contexts, including during the mining process.

**ShitCoin**

This term is used to classify fraud coins with little or no standing in the community.

**Smart Contract**

A smart contract - also known as a smart contract or digital contract - is a self-executing computer code designed to facilitate, execute, and protect financial transactions on the blockchain.

**Spread**

Difference between the buy price and the sell price in the order book (book).

**Soft fork**

Update of a coin that does not require the coin system to be restarted with a new blockchain. This usually happens without us noticing.

**swingtrader**

Trading strategy with few operations over time. Take advantage of the market fluctuations.

***T***

**taker**

Taker is the investor who has an order that will be executed immediately if he finds another opposing order.

**Target Tag**

Target tag is a code assigned to each xrp account. It is used to identify the recipient of the transaction, as if it were your house number when an order is delivered.

**Terahashes/sec - TH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in trillions of hashes (TH /s).

**testnet**

An alternative network used for test development.

**Ticker**
This is the name given to currency symbols: BTC (Bitcoin), ETH (Ethereum), LTC (Litecoin), XRP (Ripple), ADA (Cardano).

**Token**

Cryptocurrencies are coins created to be coins, while tokens are created to be distributed to people with the promise of being worth something in the future. Comparing the two to the conventional investment market, cryptocurrencies could be currencies like USD or EURO, while tokens would be the shares of a company.

**TOR**

Acronym for The Onion Router, in Portuguese. It is a routing protocol used by people who want to maintain their privacy on the net.

**TXID**

Better known as the transaction hash. This is an identifier used to reference transactions in a blockchain.

***V***

**Volatility**

Price movements of an asset.

**W**

Wallet

Wallet is where we can store digital currencies.

**Whale**

As the holder of a large portion of a given currency, the whale is a user that centralizes the currency by controlling its price.

**Withdraw**

Withdraw

***X***

**XBT**

Representation of the currency unit of bitcoin.

**XRP**

Ripple cryptocurrency ticker.

Starts with a lowercase letter and represents the monetary unit of the Bitcoin protocol.

**Bitcoin**

Starts with a capital letter and represents the protocol developed by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**Block Explorer**

Also known as a blockchain browser, this is a website or computer program that allows you to view transactions, addresses, blocks, and all the information of a blockchain and a particular cryptocurrency.

**Blockchain**

Blockchain, also known as trust protocol, is a distributed ledger technology that aims at decentralization as a security measure. It is considered Bitcoin's most important technological innovation as it is the proof of all transactions on the network. It records and stores all transactions in Bitcoin's history.

**Blockchain.info**

Company that offers a wallet service and a block explorer, confused with the Bitcoin blockchain.

**BTC**

Abbreviation for the currency unit of Bitcoin.

**Bull**

Means "Taurus" in English and is exactly the opposite of "Bear". The bull is the investor who believes in the cryptocurrency price trend. He bets on buying the currency at a low price to make a profit when the value rises.

**bullish**

It is an aggressive bottom-up chart behavior (characterized by a sharp rise and a short fall). It is also used to signal optimism for the market.

![Bulls vs Bears.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/K3PMkhgFCF2nLfjJjWA-9.png?height=1080&width=1080)

***C***

**Candlestick**

Candlestick is a graphical representation of the price of an asset. It allows to see the opening, high, low and closing prices within a time frame in the chart.

**Confirmation time**

Confirmation time is the time that elapses between a transaction being sent to the network and it being recorded in a block. Basically, it is the time a user has to wait before his transaction is confirmed on the network.

**Cold Storage**

A way to store cryptocurrencies offline, using paper, metal, or another alternative that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored or moved.

**Crypto**

Cryptography is a set of encryptions used to protect information in a way that only the sender and receiver can understand. It is used throughout the blockchain ecosystem and today by some companies like Facebook.

**Cryptocurrency**

Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies such as Bitcoin, Litecoin, Ethereum and many others that use cryptography for various purposes. Among other things, to ensure that all transactions are 100% secure.

**Custody**

To have control and ownership of assets. Having a wallet or assets in custody can also mean that your keys remain private and confidential.

**cypherpunk**

Cypherpunk is a community of online privacy and anonymity advocates. Their motto is: cypherpunks write code. They believe that those who want to protect their privacy should do it themselves instead of waiting for others to do it for them.

***D***

**Daytrader**

Investor who makes daily moves by buying and selling assets.

**Dump**

Sudden drop in the prices of cryptocurrencies.

**Dust transaction**

Transaction involving a small amount of bitcoins with little financial value, but which takes up space on the blockchain.

***E***

**ETH**

Ticker symbol of the cryptocurrency Ethereum.

**Escrow account**

Term used to describe the holding of funds in the possession of a third party to protect oneself during an operation.

**Ether**
Ethereum currency unit used to pay your blockchain fees.

**Ethereum**
Ethereum is a blockchain that permits the programming of decentralized applications, smart contracts and transactions of the cryptocurrency Ether and different tokens, as well as the creation of NFT collections and decentralized programs.

**Exchange**

Local, centralized, or decentralized exchange between cryptocurrencies and other assets, for example, exchanging dollars for bitcoin. Bitcoin exchanges are used to exchange bitcoin for FIAT coins or other cryptocurrencies.

***F***

**Faucet**

Websites that offer rewards in cryptocurrency for clicking ads or performing small tasks. Here is how: Answer a survey, provide your data, etc.

**Fee**

Fees paid on a transaction, for example: conversions, transfers and withdrawals.

**Fiat**

Conventional money (fiduciary money), i.e. money that is not a cryptocurrency, such as euros, reals, dollars, etc.

**FOMO**

Fear of missing out or fear of missing out on a profitable opportunity.

**Fork**

Updates to the cryptocurrency codes of coins, called a fork. A new coin that emerges from another, such as Bitcoin Dash, which is a fork of Bitcoin.

**Full Node**

It is the program that contains the consensus rules of the Bitcoin network and a full copy of the blockchain. Not every full node is a miner, but every miner is a full node.

***G***

**Gas**

The term gas refers to a pricing mechanism on the Ethereum network. It calculates the fees for executing a transaction or a smart contract operation.

**Genesis Block**

The first block of Bitcoin, created by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**GPU**

Graphical Processing Unit. Chip for processing complex mathematical calculations required for running games and software that require a lot of graphics resources.

***H***

**Halving**

Bitcoin halving is the emissions reduction that occurs every 4 years, as defined in the code.

**Hash**

An algorithm used by the Bitcoin protocol and other cryptocurrencies to convert a large amount of information into a fixed-length hexadecimal string of numbers.

**Hash Rate**

Number of hashes processed by a miner in a given period of time.

**HOLD**

In Portuguese, it means "to hold", i.e. we hold the asset even in the event of a significant devaluation, thinking about future valuations.

**Hot wallet**

It is a cryptocurrency wallet that is online and connected to the Internet. Like Metamask, Binance wallet, Trust wallet, Phantom and many others.

**Hype**

A term that indicates that something is the trend of the moment. For example, "NFTs are in an absurd hype".

***I***

**ICO**

Initial Coin Offering is a system for raising funds for a startup or company. Usually they come up with "revolutionary or unique ideas" that are applied on a blockchain.

**IDO**

Initial Dex Offering, A IDO is a crypto token offering conducted on a decentralized exchange (DEX).

**INPUT**

Origin address of a bitcoin transaction. A single transaction can have multiple origin addresses.

***K***

***Kilohashes/second - kH/s***

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in thousands of hashes.

***KYC***

Know your customer, in Portuguese. These are guidelines that government institutions impose on companies to find out who they are doing business with, i.e. they have data and documents of their customers.

***L***

**Ledger**

The ledger is a shared record of information, like a bank cash book, a book where all financial transactions in a bank are recorded, the ledger would be a place where transactions of cryptocurrencies running on the blockchain are recorded. . Today, it is also a wallet that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored without an internet connection.

**Liquidity**

It is the ability to buy or sell an asset easily, even in large quantities.

![Ledger used to store private keys securely.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eqe_0q0uws5zc_0jzyNZl.png?height=438&width=500)

***M***

**Malleability**

Ability to change uncommitted transactions without invalidating them.

**Manufacturer**

Maker is a term used when you place an order and it is not immediately traded. The order stays on the order book waiting for someone else to send a counter order so it can be executed.

**Marketcap**

The famous market cap. Amount of cryptocurrency circulating X crypto price.

**Megahashes/sec - MH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in millions of hashes.

**MicroBit - uBTC**

One millionth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.000001 BTC.

**MilliBit - mBTC**

One thousandth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.001 BTC.

**Mining**

This is the process of performing mathematical calculations. When a computer performs these cryptographic calculations, it receives a reward, X Bitcoin. We say that it mines and creates more Bitcoin.

**Mixer**

Service that encrypts the input and output of transactions to maintain privacy and reduce traceability.

***N***

**Node**

Device connected to the Bitcoin network that uses a computer program to forward transactions to other nodes, creating a decentralized network.

***O***

**Order:**

Market order that executes the purchase regardless of the price.

STOP -LIMIT orde - You choose a price and tell the system: "When the currency reaches X dollars, place an order LIMIT for Y dollars".

**Output**

Destination address for a bitcoin transaction. It is possible for a transaction to have multiple outputs.

***P***

**P2P**

P2P (Peer-to-Peer). Bitcoin was designed as a peer-to-peer system, meaning it does not need intermediaries, such as central banks, to broker a transaction between two people. In the market, this term is used to describe the trading of cryptocurrencies between two parties without the need for an exchange.

**Paper wallet**

It is considered a very safe way to store your cryptocurrencies, as they are not exposed to much risk precisely because they are offline. Since you do not need access to the Internet, it's basically a piece of paper that contains your private and public keys.

**Phishing**

In phishing, the user clicks on or downloads a fake file to steal information. Due to the popularity of cryptocurrencies, fake emails, files that change the victim's router settings or Google ads are spread more and more often to make the site appear first.

**Pool**

A collection of miners who join together to mine a block, and then divide the rewards among themselves. Mining pools are a great way to increase the probability of success as the difficulty increases.

**PoW**

It is the proof that a transaction has been validated and is legitimate. Using a mathematical function (SHA -256), transactions are encrypted and sent to the network where miners compete to decrypt them.

**Profit**

When we buy/ sell crypto and make profits.

**Pump**

When the price of a currency goes up.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3yfkb1zB1zKx5CtrUtCRZ.png?height=576&width=1024)

***R***

**Rekt**

The correct term would be "Wrecked", which means "ruined". It is the investor who has lost everything and ruined his equity when the price falls.

**ROI**

The return on an investment.

***s***

**Satoshi**

Smallest part of a Bitcoin = 0.00000001 BTC. If someone says they have 10 Satoshis, it means they have 0.00000010 BTC.

**Satoshi Nakamoto**

The name of the alleged inventor of Bitcoin.

**Scam**

Scams and frauds that are very common in cryptocurrency projects.

**ScamCoin**

Altcoin created with the purpose of defrauding users and enriching creators.

**SEPA**

Single European Payments Area, Portuguese, Single European Payments Area, is an integrated payment system between the countries of the Eurozone that allows the transfer of funds between banks and different countries. The transfer process is similar to the TED /DOC that we have in Brazil, but in the case of SEPA it includes all countries that use the euro.

**SHA-256**

Hash-like mathematical function used in Bitcoin in various contexts, including during the mining process.

**ShitCoin**

This term is used to classify fraud coins with little or no standing in the community.

**Smart Contract**

A smart contract - also known as a smart contract or digital contract - is a self-executing computer code designed to facilitate, execute, and protect financial transactions on the blockchain.

**Spread**

Difference between the buy price and the sell price in the order book (book).

**Soft fork**

Update of a coin that does not require the coin system to be restarted with a new blockchain. This usually happens without us noticing.

**swingtrader**

Trading strategy with few operations over time. Take advantage of the market fluctuations.

***T***

**taker**

Taker is the investor who has an order that will be executed immediately if he finds another opposing order.

**Target Tag**

Target tag is a code assigned to each xrp account. It is used to identify the recipient of the transaction, as if it were your house number when an order is delivered.

**Terahashes/sec - TH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in trillions of hashes (TH /s).

**testnet**

An alternative network used for test development.

**Ticker**
This is the name given to currency symbols: BTC (Bitcoin), ETH (Ethereum), LTC (Litecoin), XRP (Ripple), ADA (Cardano).

**Token**

Cryptocurrencies are coins created to be coins, while tokens are created to be distributed to people with the promise of being worth something in the future. Comparing the two to the conventional investment market, cryptocurrencies could be currencies like USD or EURO, while tokens would be the shares of a company.

**TOR**

Acronym for The Onion Router, in Portuguese. It is a routing protocol used by people who want to maintain their privacy on the net.

**TXID**

Better known as the transaction hash. This is an identifier used to reference transactions in a blockchain.

***V***

**Volatility**

Price movements of an asset.

**W**

Wallet

Wallet is where we can store digital currencies.

**Whale**

As the holder of a large portion of a given currency, the whale is a user that centralizes the currency by controlling its price.

**Withdraw**

Withdraw

***X***

**XBT**

Representation of the currency unit of bitcoin.

**XRP**

Ripple cryptocurrency ticker.

title: Starknet Alpha 0.7.0
body:
[Initialement publié ](https://medium.com/starkware/starknet-alpha-0-7-0-26e04db03509)en anglais par StarkWare le 9 avril 2021.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ryv4drFBPE65JgMBtl874.png?height=473&width=1400)

*Spoiler – alerte version importante !*

## **TL;DR**

* StarkNet Alpha 0.7.0 sorti sur Goerli; avec pleins d’améliorations
* Les contrats peuvent désormais être mis à niveau en utilisant le Proxy Upgrade Pattern
* Les contrats peuvent désormais émettre des Événements
* Prise en charge des appels système tant attendus Block Number et Block Timestamp

## **Introduction**

Nous sommes heureux de sortir Alpha 0.7.0, une version pleine de nouvelles fonctionnalités et d’améliorations. L’un des meilleurs stimulants de StarkNet au cours des derniers mois a été la participation accrue de la communauté à façonner l’avenir de StarkNet. Cette version répond à certains des besoins ardant de la communauté.

**Modifications apportées à la Convention sur la dénomination**

Le lecteur attentif a peut-être remarqué que la version précédente de StarkNet Alpha s’appelait Alpha 4, alors que nous sortons maintenant Alpha 0.7.0. Nous avons décidé d’omettre le numéro de version Alpha dédié et de nous baser uniquement sur la version cairo-lang associée.

## **Nouvelles Fonctionnalités**

### **Possibilité d’évolutivité du contrat**

Le [Proxy Upgrade Pattern](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/upgrades-plugins/1.x/proxies) d’OpenZeppelin est désormais entièrement pris en charge pour les mises à niveau de contrat dans StarkNet. Le modèle Proxy est la méthode commune pour permettre des mises à niveau de contrat sur Ethereum. Alpha 0.7.0 permet ce modèle sur StarkNet.

Nous avons fait un court [tutoriel](https://starknet.io/docs/hello_starknet/default_entrypoint.html) pour montrer une implémentation de base, et OpenZeppelin travaille déjà dur pour implémenter un contrat standard pour le modèle proxy; [voir le prototype](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/pull/129).

### **Block Number et Block Timestamp**

Alpha 0.7.0 ajoute deux nouveaux appels système que beaucoup de développeurs ont demandé. Ces appels permettent à un contrat d’accéder au numéro de bloc et à l’horodatage du bloc. Le numéro de bloc retourne le numéro du bloc en cours d’exécution. L’horodatage du bloc retourne l’horodatage donné par le séquenceur lors de la création du bloc.

Vous pouvez voir un exemple d’utilisation de ces fonctionnalités dans le [tutoriel](https://starknet.io/docs/hello_starknet/more_features.html#block-number-and-timestamp).

### **Événements**

Surprise ! Une fonctionnalité qui a été prévue pour une future version s’est glissée dans celle-ci.

Les contrats StarkNet prennent désormais en charge la définition et l’émission d’événements, ce qui leur permet d’exposer des informations d’exécution pour les applications off-chain à consommer. Les développeurs Ethereum trouveront la sémantique et la syntaxe très similaire à Solidity. Vous pouvez lire la [documentation](https://starknet.io/documentation/events/), ou suivre le tutoriel, qui explique cette fonctionnalité.

### **Directive %builtins supprimée**

La directive %builtin n’est plus nécessaire dans les contrats StarkNet. Ce changement fait suite à une discussion communautaire sur le [modèle d’extensibilité des contrats](https://community.starknet.io/t/contract-extensibility-pattern/210) sur [StarkNet Shamans](https://community.starknet.io/). Il simplifie considérablement la facilité d’utilisation de ce modèle d’extensibilité.

Par exemple, le contrat suivant sera modifié : 

```
%lang starknet

# This is the "%builtins" directive.

# It is not needed anymore.

%builtins range_check

@view 

func add(x : felt, y : felt) -> (res : felt):

return (res=x + y)end
```

En cela :

```
%lang starknet

@view

func add(x : felt, y : felt) -> (res : felt):

return (res=x + y)

end
```

Vous pouvez consulter les contrats standard [ERC-20](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/tree/main/contracts/token), qui utilisent le nouveau modèle.

## **Fonctions externes Support des tableaux de structures**

Alpha 0.7.0 prend en charge la transmission et le retour de tableaux de structs¹ dans les fonctions externes. Cette fonctionnalité supplémentaire permet aux contrats de compte de mieux prendre en charge les [appels multiples](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/pull/73#discussion_r753535751).

Multicall est une fonctionnalité puissante de Account Abstraction qui permet à un compte d’effectuer plusieurs appels en une seule transaction. Un cas d’utilisation évident est celui de créer une **transaction unique** qui appelle allocation puis transferFrom.

Nous avons hâte de voir ce que la communauté en fera.

## **Améliorations apportées à StarkNet CLI**

### **Prise en charge des blocs en attente**

Les [blocs en attente](https://starknet.io/documentation/block-structure-and-hash/#pending_block) ont été [introduits](https://community.starknet.io/t/cairo-v0-6-2-api-change-pending-block/195) dans la dernière version mineure (v0.6.2) et offraient des confirmations plus rapides sur les transactions. Cette version inclut le support pour interroger ces blocs via le StarkNet CLI.

Pour l’utiliser, dans chaque commande CLI qui prend block_number comme argument (contract_call/get_block/get_code/get_storage_at), nous pouvons interroger le StarkNet en ce qui concerne le bloc en attente en spécifiant block_number=pending.

### **Soutien aux contrats de compte**

StarkNet utilise l’abstraction de compte, c’est-à-dire que tous les comptes sont implémentés comme des contrats intelligents. Les premières implémentations de contrats de compte ont été faites par [Argent](https://github.com/argentlabs/argent-contracts-starknet) et OZ, mais nous nous attendons à bien d’autres.

Dans StarkNet, toutes les transactions doivent passer par un contrat de compte, et le CLI permet désormais d’interagir directement avec StarkNet Alpha par le biais de contrats de compte. Voir le [tutoriel](https://starknet.io/docs/hello_starknet/account_setup.html#setting-up-a-starknet-account) pour savoir comment le configurer.

Des fonctionnalités similaires ont également été ajoutées à [StarkNet.py](http://starknet.py/) et à [Nile](https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/nile) le mois dernier.

## La messagerie L1<>L2 dans le cadre des tests

Alpha 0.7.0 introduit le Postman. Le Postman permet aux développeurs d'utiliser le cadre de test pour tester des flux plus complexes.

À un niveau élevé, il imite la responsabilité du séquenceur StarkNet de transmettre des messages de L1 à L2 et de L2 à L1. Il s’assure que les messages envoyés via le contrat de messagerie Solidity apparaîtront dans le contrat StarkNet de destination et les messages envoyés depuis un contrat StarkNet apparaîtront dans le contrat de messagerie Solidity.

## **Et plus de fonctionnalités**

Alpha 0.7.0 apporte de nombreuses autres fonctionnalités et modifications, comme l'ajout d'une fonction efficace de racine carrée à la bibliothèque commune de mathématiques. Une liste complète figure dans le journal des [modifications](https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/releases/tag/v0.7.0).

### **Prochainement ?**

Le support initial de [Fee Mechanism](https://community.starknet.io/t/fees-in-starknet-alpha/286/29) sera publié dans quelques semaines, sous la forme d’une sous-version de StarkNet.

### **Plus d’informations?**

[starknet.io](http://starknet.io/): pour toutes les informations StarkNet, tutoriels et mises à jour.

[StarkNet Discord](https://discord.com/invite/uJ9HZTUk2Y): rejoignez-nous pour obtenir des réponses à vos questions, obtenir le support de développement et faire partie de la communauté.

[StarkNet Shamans](https://community.starknet.io/): rejoignez-vous pour suivre (et participer !) les discussions de recherche StarkNet.

¹struct (C programming language) plus d’informations [ici](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Struct_(C_programming_language))

*Traduction faite par [@cleminso](https://twitter.com/cleminso)*

title: Berry Thicket
body:
In the sunless labyrinth of the berry thicket, 
 10,000 thorns did kiss my flesh. 
 I became stuck in their kisses,  
 stuck in their hands, never to be released  
 from their fingers again.

I became an old man in that sunlessness; 
 I forgot my fingers, my feet, the eyes of my face,  
 the road by which I had once arrived 
 and the berries for which I had once came. 

I am now only a heaving chest 
 suspended in kisses, listening to the birds  
 who sing from beyond the thicket, breathing  
 like gods from soft throats, until one day 

they, too, fall silent— 
 they, too.

title: VIPs01 我们需要在田园上UGC
body:
我们在建设一个村子，位于浙江·太湖南部，靠近上海和杭州。村子有很多古宅，白墙黛瓦，清民风范，保留这样的气质，设计成古风文旅会有很好的沉浸感，应邀的来访者都有好感。这坚定了我们要悉心设计内容的决心。

内容建设和基建不同，集思广益，需要UGC，因此我们希望通过Web3协作共同展开叙事…

![正射影像](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iSVa4Hg7CGGsrvw3oH-VL.jpg?height=500&width=1500)

150户古宅（宅基地）可以改造成商业集群运营20年。民宿、酒肆、茶馆、画廊、曲苑…清明上河繁荣，元宇宙实境。

![古法新酿](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/FT7d9xqakTqvVkBV9ExE_.jpg?height=692&width=1440)

古村2020年获得“美丽乡村”立项，桥梁、村道、植被、景观等基础环境改造已经启动。目前基础建设是以公司的组织形式开展的，具体情况会在后面新启篇幅以及AMA中解答。

![环境改造](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/O2cKza-N4ohf-o_DCSOiR.jpg?height=300&width=1500)

我们希望代入Web3机制的是“内容叙事”和“运营方式”，这两方面分别定义成“Storyliving”和“Time Bank”。

Storyliving一词来自于迪士尼在加州·奥兰多开发的商业地产项目。当全世界都在围绕Meta建设虚拟场景元宇宙的时候，地球上最会讲故事的公司--迪士尼表示，元宇宙应该是肉身住在童话小镇里，思绪荡漾在故事里。我们也认为，沉浸式的文旅小镇能够带给居住者丰富的生命体验，是贯穿于虚实的元宇宙平台。

Time Bank是流行于欧洲和北美的一种将“付出”(服务)储值的方式，人们之间的相互帮助，或者无形的付出可以被记录、转移、提取，这和基于区块链的数字经济十分相似，我们希望可以借此驱动小镇元宇宙生态。

title: Crypto dictionary
body:
***[Read it in portuguese](https://mirror.xyz/0x07121d1002B35011B4118751bf6Dca5AC282915E/Sh04-WuqtmVdnNooEeVLkMRdTNwm4U8FtsQ_qUca-vw)***

Bitico appeared in 2009, but it was the beginning of the end. To help you understand a bit more about these terms and interact with the cryptoassets universe, we have prepared a complete dictionary of all the most commonly used slang in this medium.

kgujykfvugckythc

***A***

**Addy**

Address of a cryptocurrency wallet.

**Altcoin**

Term for alternative currencies to Bitcoin. Example: Eth, Litecoin, Dogecoin, Dash, Aioz, etc.

**ABC**

Acronym for anti-money laundering, in Portuguese: anti-money laundering. These are techniques to prevent money laundering, such as receiving money only through a bank transfer and the account holder itself, as Brazilian exchanges already do.

**Ask price**

This is the minimum price at which someone is willing to sell their asset.

**ASIC**

Application-specific integrated circuit acronym, in Portuguese: application-specific integrated circuits. Chip designed specifically for a particular task, e.g. in the case of Bitcoin, ASICs were designed to process a SHA -256 hash and mine Bitcoins.

**ATH**

The highest price ever reached by a particular cryptocurrency.

**Active**

Refers to a person's assets. For example, if there is $5,000.00 in a bank account, these are the assets in that bank account. In the case of cryptocurrencies, "Digital Assets" or "Crypto Assets".

**ATM**

ATM or in Portuguese: electronic box. where users can buy and sell Bitcoin using physical cash or debit cards. They are available in Brazil around the world, including some cities 

![Metamask wallet, arrow to reference the address.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KAZsRH_1E0HrxwBTBwrEI.png?height=726&width=1280)

***B***

**Ballast**

It is an asset that aims to provide a guarantee, i.e. it combines an initially worthless asset with something that has an implicit value. Today there are assets backed by BTC, DOLLAR, REAL, etc.

**Bear**

From the English, "Bear." The "Bear" is an investor who believes that the price of a cryptocurrency can fall at any moment. Thus, the Bear sells his assets before they depreciate too much. When we say that a market is "Bearish", it means that there are more sell orders than buy orders at that moment.

**Bearish**

This is an aggressive top-down chart behavior (characterized by a sharp decline and a short rally).

**bitcoin**

Starts with a lowercase letter and represents the monetary unit of the Bitcoin protocol.

**Bitcoin**

Starts with a capital letter and represents the protocol developed by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**Block Explorer**

Also known as a blockchain browser, this is a website or computer program that allows you to view transactions, addresses, blocks, and all the information of a blockchain and a particular cryptocurrency.

**Blockchain**

Blockchain, also known as trust protocol, is a distributed ledger technology that aims at decentralization as a security measure. It is considered Bitcoin's most important technological innovation as it is the proof of all transactions on the network. It records and stores all transactions in Bitcoin's history.

**Blockchain.info**

Company that offers a wallet service and a block explorer, confused with the Bitcoin blockchain.

**BTC**

Abbreviation for the currency unit of Bitcoin.

**Bull**

Means "Taurus" in English and is exactly the opposite of "Bear". The bull is the investor who believes in the cryptocurrency price trend. He bets on buying the currency at a low price to make a profit when the value rises.

**bullish**

It is an aggressive bottom-up chart behavior (characterized by a sharp rise and a short fall). It is also used to signal optimism for the market.

![Bulls vs Bears.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/K3PMkhgFCF2nLfjJjWA-9.png?height=1080&width=1080)

***C***

**Candlestick**

Candlestick is a graphical representation of the price of an asset. It allows to see the opening, high, low and closing prices within a time frame in the chart.

**Confirmation time**

Confirmation time is the time that elapses between a transaction being sent to the network and it being recorded in a block. Basically, it is the time a user has to wait before his transaction is confirmed on the network.

**Cold Storage**

A way to store cryptocurrencies offline, using paper, metal, or another alternative that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored or moved.

**Crypto**

Cryptography is a set of encryptions used to protect information in a way that only the sender and receiver can understand. It is used throughout the blockchain ecosystem and today by some companies like Facebook.

**Cryptocurrency**

Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies such as Bitcoin, Litecoin, Ethereum and many others that use cryptography for various purposes. Among other things, to ensure that all transactions are 100% secure.

**Custody**

To have control and ownership of assets. Having a wallet or assets in custody can also mean that your keys remain private and confidential.

**cypherpunk**

Cypherpunk is a community of online privacy and anonymity advocates. Their motto is: cypherpunks write code. They believe that those who want to protect their privacy should do it themselves instead of waiting for others to do it for them.

***D***

**Daytrader**

Investor who makes daily moves by buying and selling assets.

**Dump**

Sudden drop in the prices of cryptocurrencies.

**Dust transaction**

Transaction involving a small amount of bitcoins with little financial value, but which takes up space on the blockchain.

***E***

**ETH**

Ticker symbol of the cryptocurrency Ethereum.

**Escrow account**

Term used to describe the holding of funds in the possession of a third party to protect oneself during an operation.

**Ether**
Ethereum currency unit used to pay your blockchain fees.

**Ethereum**
Ethereum is a blockchain that permits the programming of decentralized applications, smart contracts and transactions of the cryptocurrency Ether and different tokens, as well as the creation of NFT collections and decentralized programs.

**Exchange**

Local, centralized, or decentralized exchange between cryptocurrencies and other assets, for example, exchanging dollars for bitcoin. Bitcoin exchanges are used to exchange bitcoin for FIAT coins or other cryptocurrencies.

***F***

**Faucet**

Websites that offer rewards in cryptocurrency for clicking ads or performing small tasks. Here is how: Answer a survey, provide your data, etc.

**Fee**

Fees paid on a transaction, for example: conversions, transfers and withdrawals.

**Fiat**

Conventional money (fiduciary money), i.e. money that is not a cryptocurrency, such as euros, reals, dollars, etc.

**FOMO**

Fear of missing out or fear of missing out on a profitable opportunity.

**Fork**

Updates to the cryptocurrency codes of coins, called a fork. A new coin that emerges from another, such as Bitcoin Dash, which is a fork of Bitcoin.

**Full Node**

It is the program that contains the consensus rules of the Bitcoin network and a full copy of the blockchain. Not every full node is a miner, but every miner is a full node.

***G***

**Gas**

The term gas refers to a pricing mechanism on the Ethereum network. It calculates the fees for executing a transaction or a smart contract operation.

**Genesis Block**

The first block of Bitcoin, created by Satoshi Nakamoto.

**GPU**

Graphical Processing Unit. Chip for processing complex mathematical calculations required for running games and software that require a lot of graphics resources.

***H***

**Halving**

Bitcoin halving is the emissions reduction that occurs every 4 years, as defined in the code.

**Hash**

An algorithm used by the Bitcoin protocol and other cryptocurrencies to convert a large amount of information into a fixed-length hexadecimal string of numbers.

**Hash Rate**

Number of hashes processed by a miner in a given period of time.

**HOLD**

In Portuguese, it means "to hold", i.e. we hold the asset even in the event of a significant devaluation, thinking about future valuations.

**Hot wallet**

It is a cryptocurrency wallet that is online and connected to the Internet. Like Metamask, Binance wallet, Trust wallet, Phantom and many others.

**Hype**

A term that indicates that something is the trend of the moment. For example, "NFTs are in an absurd hype".

***I***

**ICO**

Initial Coin Offering is a system for raising funds for a startup or company. Usually they come up with "revolutionary or unique ideas" that are applied on a blockchain.

**IDO**

Initial Dex Offering, A IDO is a crypto token offering conducted on a decentralized exchange (DEX).

**INPUT**

Origin address of a bitcoin transaction. A single transaction can have multiple origin addresses.

***K***

***Kilohashes/second - kH/s***

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in thousands of hashes.

***KYC***

Know your customer, in Portuguese. These are guidelines that government institutions impose on companies to find out who they are doing business with, i.e. they have data and documents of their customers.

***L***

**Ledger**

The ledger is a shared record of information, like a bank cash book, a book where all financial transactions in a bank are recorded, the ledger would be a place where transactions of cryptocurrencies running on the blockchain are recorded. . Today, it is also a wallet that allows cryptocurrencies to be stored without an internet connection.

**Liquidity**

It is the ability to buy or sell an asset easily, even in large quantities.

![Ledger used to store private keys securely.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eqe_0q0uws5zc_0jzyNZl.png?height=438&width=500)

***M***

**Malleability**

Ability to change uncommitted transactions without invalidating them.

**Manufacturer**

Maker is a term used when you place an order and it is not immediately traded. The order stays on the order book waiting for someone else to send a counter order so it can be executed.

**Marketcap**

The famous market cap. Amount of cryptocurrency circulating X crypto price.

**Megahashes/sec - MH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in millions of hashes.

**MicroBit - uBTC**

One millionth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.000001 BTC.

**MilliBit - mBTC**

One thousandth part of 1 Bitcoin or 0.001 BTC.

**Mining**

This is the process of performing mathematical calculations. When a computer performs these cryptographic calculations, it receives a reward, X Bitcoin. We say that it mines and creates more Bitcoin.

**Mixer**

Service that encrypts the input and output of transactions to maintain privacy and reduce traceability.

***N***

**Node**

Device connected to the Bitcoin network that uses a computer program to forward transactions to other nodes, creating a decentralized network.

***O***

**Order:**

Market order that executes the purchase regardless of the price.

STOP -LIMIT orde - You choose a price and tell the system: "When the currency reaches X dollars, place an order LIMIT for Y dollars".

**Output**

Destination address for a bitcoin transaction. It is possible for a transaction to have multiple outputs.

***P***

**P2P**

P2P (Peer-to-Peer). Bitcoin was designed as a peer-to-peer system, meaning it does not need intermediaries, such as central banks, to broker a transaction between two people. In the market, this term is used to describe the trading of cryptocurrencies between two parties without the need for an exchange.

**Paper wallet**

It is considered a very safe way to store your cryptocurrencies, as they are not exposed to much risk precisely because they are offline. Since you do not need access to the Internet, it's basically a piece of paper that contains your private and public keys.

**Phishing**

In phishing, the user clicks on or downloads a fake file to steal information. Due to the popularity of cryptocurrencies, fake emails, files that change the victim's router settings or Google ads are spread more and more often to make the site appear first.

**Pool**

A collection of miners who join together to mine a block, and then divide the rewards among themselves. Mining pools are a great way to increase the probability of success as the difficulty increases.

**PoW**

It is the proof that a transaction has been validated and is legitimate. Using a mathematical function (SHA -256), transactions are encrypted and sent to the network where miners compete to decrypt them.

**Profit**

When we buy/ sell crypto and make profits.

**Pump**

When the price of a currency goes up.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3yfkb1zB1zKx5CtrUtCRZ.png?height=576&width=1024)

***R***

**Rekt**

The correct term would be "Wrecked", which means "ruined". It is the investor who has lost everything and ruined his equity when the price falls.

**ROI**

The return on an investment.

***s***

**Satoshi**

Smallest part of a Bitcoin = 0.00000001 BTC. If someone says they have 10 Satoshis, it means they have 0.00000010 BTC.

**Satoshi Nakamoto**

The name of the alleged inventor of Bitcoin.

**Scam**

Scams and frauds that are very common in cryptocurrency projects.

**ScamCoin**

Altcoin created with the purpose of defrauding users and enriching creators.

**SEPA**

Single European Payments Area, Portuguese, Single European Payments Area, is an integrated payment system between the countries of the Eurozone that allows the transfer of funds between banks and different countries. The transfer process is similar to the TED /DOC that we have in Brazil, but in the case of SEPA it includes all countries that use the euro.

**SHA-256**

Hash-like mathematical function used in Bitcoin in various contexts, including during the mining process.

**ShitCoin**

This term is used to classify fraud coins with little or no standing in the community.

**Smart Contract**

A smart contract - also known as a smart contract or digital contract - is a self-executing computer code designed to facilitate, execute, and protect financial transactions on the blockchain.

**Spread**

Difference between the buy price and the sell price in the order book (book).

**Soft fork**

Update of a coin that does not require the coin system to be restarted with a new blockchain. This usually happens without us noticing.

**swingtrader**

Trading strategy with few operations over time. Take advantage of the market fluctuations.

***T***

**taker**

Taker is the investor who has an order that will be executed immediately if he finds another opposing order.

**Target Tag**

Target tag is a code assigned to each xrp account. It is used to identify the recipient of the transaction, as if it were your house number when an order is delivered.

**Terahashes/sec - TH /s**

Number of possible attempts to resolve a hash in a given second, measured in trillions of hashes (TH /s).

**testnet**

An alternative network used for test development.

**Ticker**
This is the name given to currency symbols: BTC (Bitcoin), ETH (Ethereum), LTC (Litecoin), XRP (Ripple), ADA (Cardano).

**Token**

Cryptocurrencies are coins created to be coins, while tokens are created to be distributed to people with the promise of being worth something in the future. Comparing the two to the conventional investment market, cryptocurrencies could be currencies like USD or EURO, while tokens would be the shares of a company.

**TOR**

Acronym for The Onion Router, in Portuguese. It is a routing protocol used by people who want to maintain their privacy on the net.

**TXID**

Better known as the transaction hash. This is an identifier used to reference transactions in a blockchain.

***V***

**Volatility**

Price movements of an asset.

**W**

Wallet

Wallet is where we can store digital currencies.

**Whale**

As the holder of a large portion of a given currency, the whale is a user that centralizes the currency by controlling its price.

**Withdraw**

Withdraw

***X***

**XBT**

Representation of the currency unit of bitcoin.

**XRP**

Ripple cryptocurrency ticker.

title: O que são NFTs?
body:
## Definição

A tecnologia dos NFTs, **Non-Fungible Tokens**, foi creada em 2017 através de contratos inteligentes na blockchain Ethereum. No início de 2021, os NFTs entram de repente em destaque no mundo das criptomoedas e tecnologia subjacente (blockchain).

Um NFT é um tipo de token. **Mas o que são tokens?**

**Tokens** são unidades virtuais que confirmam a posse de certo activo digital. Os tokens operam com base na tecnologia blockchain, aquela que está na base das criptomoedas. Para entender melhor os conceitos **blockchain** e **criptomoeda**, recomendo a leitura deste artigo:

[https://mirror.xyz/0x2DBF911D78815D995B05bc8FA42e378f78D7CC7b/0vQjECsvCIYUAkSbXuKWo3Jncbsg3ZiaaS0-2fraLnQ](https://mirror.xyz/0x2DBF911D78815D995B05bc8FA42e378f78D7CC7b/0vQjECsvCIYUAkSbXuKWo3Jncbsg3ZiaaS0-2fraLnQ)

Entre todos os tokens existentes (mais de 13 000 neste momento - o site [Coingecko](https://www.coingecko.com/) chama-os todos de ‘Coins’, mas na realidade só alguns são moedas) há alguns que se chamam moedas. Uma moeda, ou criptomoeda, é semelhante a uma moeda física, e é um token nativo de certa blockchain. Cada blockchain só tem uma moeda, mas pode ter vários tokens. As moedas tipicamente têm o mesmo nome da blockchain onde operam. Por exemplo, [SOLANA](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/solana) (SOL) é a moeda da blockchain Solana, e [SOLCIAL](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/solcial) (SLCL) é um token que opera nessa mesma blockchain. Por exemplo, [ETHEREUM ou ETHER](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/ethereum) (ETH) é a moeda da blockchain Ethereum, e [BASIC ATTENTION TOKEN](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/basic-attention-token) (BAT) é um token que opera nessa mesma blockchain. Note-se que tokens que não sejam nativos, i.e não sejam moedas, podem existir em várias blockchains, como é o caso do BAT (tal facto está indicado no campo ‘Contract’, menu **…**, em **Info** - ver link acima).

Os portadores de tokens podem, além de os guardar nas suas carteiras digitais, trocá-los por outros tokens em casas de cambio online, vendê-los (NFTs) em *marketplaces*, oferecê-los, ou usá-los para comprar algo. Existem vários tipos de tokens, entre os quais destaco:

* **Pagamento** – usado para efectuar transações financeiras no mundo digital (moedas como Solana, Cardano, Bitcoin, Ethereum).
* **Utilitário** – usado para dar acesso a produtos ou serviços baseados em alguma blockchain.

  Todos os tipos anteriores são **fungíveis** (*fungible tokens*), ou seja, podem ser trocados por algo de valor igual – 1 Bitcoin na mão da pessoa A vale o mesmo que 1 Bitcoin na mão da pessoa B, ou seja, se as pessoas trocarem as moedas o cenário não se altera. Tal não se passa com os NFTs, pois cada um é único. Diz-se por isso que são **não-fungíveis**.
* **NFT** – certificados digitais únicos de trabalhos originais, onde o criador original terá sempre controlo sobre a forma como o trabalho é licensiado. São compostos por vários elementos, tais como:
  * **conteúdo digital** que representa – ficheiro de imagem, audio, texto, ou vídeo.
  * **criador** – identificação do criador do token.
  * **proprietário** – identificação do actual proprietário do token, o qual será ainda o criador se o token não tiver sido oferecido ou vendido.
  * **preço ou ofertas**, caso esteja à venda ou em leilão.
  * **metadados** – informações sobre o activo digital, como assinatura do criador, descrição, tipo de ficheiro, resolução, histórico de transações, data e hora da sua criação, …

Outra diferença entre **NFTs** e tokens fungíveis (como moedas, por exemplo) é a **indivisibilidade** dos primeiros. Por exemplo, poderás enviar 0.05 Bitcoins a um amigo, mas não poderás fazer o mesmo com 5% de um NFT.

## Valor

Se todos os criadores digitais publicarem os seus novos trabalhos, originais, como NFT, todo aquele que tentar copiar o seu trabalho e certificá-lo como NFT, muito dificilmente terá o seu trabalho reconhecido como original. Isto porque existem mecanismos (e cada vez existirão mais) para saber se certo conteúdo digital já foi publicado mais que uma vez na web como NFT (e.g, vários marketplaces fazem essa fiscalização, em breve existirão **motores de busca de NFTs** – ver websites em baixo, e poderás usar o [motor de busca da Google](https://images.google.com/) para saber a localização de certo ficheiro de imagem).

[https://nftsearch.site/](https://nftsearch.site/)

**Nota**: *se ainda não existir na base de dados, deverás/poderás adicionar o NFT que procuras à mesma*.

[https://hebys.io/](https://hebys.io/)

[https://nftlab.com/](https://nftlab.com/)

[https://nooft.io/](https://nooft.io/)

Regra geral, é possível salvar ou copiar o conteúdo digital de um NFT, seja uma imagem, vídeo, áudio ou documento, mas nunca será possível copiar o NFT. Esse terá sempre um único proprietário. Uma pessoa que crie um NFT com base na cópia  (ficheiro, screenshot) do conteúdo digital de outro NFT, terá sempre em sua posse um NFT distinto, publicado em data posterior à do original.

> *Markets for traditional art and collectibles are thriving despite forgeries, and the issue is even smaller with NFTs* ([ref](https://archive.ph/ptRTw))

Os NFTs podem ser programados para permitir ao criador/autor arrecadar dinheiro sempre que o NFT for vendido, normalmente entre 2.5% a 10% do preço de venda.

## Como Criar e Comercializar?

Qualquer pessoa pode criar algo digitalmente, transformá-lo num NFT em alguma blockchain (processo chamado ‘Minting’ em Inglês), e colocar esse token para venda em algum *marketplace* online. Alguns locais cobram para publiar os teus NFTs. Qualquer marketplace cobra uma taxa do valor de venda de cada NFT, a qual poderá ser suportada pelo comprador ou pelo vendedor, dependendo da plataforma.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GGvxJ9xOJMs4wmx6mBN0S.png?height=530&width=1127)

De modo a poderes comprar um NFT, precisarás de dispor na tua carteira digital da criptomoeda associada à blockchain onde o token está alojado.

### Marketplaces

Neste momento, os seguintes mercados permitem-te criar e por a venda NFTs gratuitamente:

title: 时事通讯 #11
body:
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*TOBmWpsryFKscFcKQIQzpw.jpeg)

🚰 Neon Faucet 已部署
🚧 Mempool 取得进展
✅ 合同实施更新
🛡️ 安全审计
🏗️ Neon 代理：跟踪 API
🏅 Neon dApp 竞赛
🔜 我们将参加的即将举行
的活动 👥 发展团队
✉️ 保持联系

## 霓虹龙头部署

新的 Neon Faucet 已部署在 devnet 上。水龙头是一个一站式商店，让开发人员可以访问主要 ERC-20 代币的 devnet 版本以及 devnet NEON 代币。devnet 代币流动性的增加将简化开发人员对新程序的测试。

请求令牌包括以下步骤：

1. 在你的钱包里切换到 Neon 网络。
2. 导航至[此处](https://neonfaucet.org/)的水龙头。
3. 连接你的钱包。
4. 开始请求可用的 ERC-20 devnet 代币和 Neon devnet 代币。

注意：用户每分钟最多只能请求 100 个令牌。

## 使用内存池取得进步

我们目前正在为 Neon Proxy 实现内存池。暂定的开发时间表旨在让工作在一个月内完成。

MemPool（内存池的缩写）是未确认或待处理事务的内存等待区域。Neon MemPool 负责按照 Solana 兼容的顺序收集和执行 Neon 交易。

## 合同实施更新

Neon Labs 团队已经实施了所有必要的更改，以支持 Solana 核心中的预编译合约。我们现在正在为 Solana 核心创建拉取请求以完成改进。

以下用 Solidity 语言编写的合约现在可以在 Solana 上运行：

* bigModExp — 用于 EVM 内部的高效 RSA 验证，以及其他形式的基于数论的密码学
* bn256Add - 对椭圆曲线操作执行加法
* bn256ScalarMult — 对椭圆曲线操作执行标量乘法
* bn256Pairing — 椭圆曲线配对操作，用于在块气体限制内执行 zk-STARK 验证

## 安全审计

为了确保开发人员和用户的最大安全性，Neon EVM 已经通过（并将继续通过）一系列安全审计。我们的治理插件已与标准 SPL 治理方法打包在一起，并已发送给我们的审计员。我们现在正在等待审查。Neon Labs 将本着向社区提供完全透明的精神报告有关结果的任何重要新闻。

## Neon 代理：跟踪 API

我们正在努力实现一个跟踪 API。该 API 将为开发人员提供在整个以太坊链上执行的任何交易的完整外部性跟踪。他们将能够重新运行历史交易，在历史状态上运行新交易，并在每次指令执行后分析区块链的状态。

我们将在未来几天发布一篇专门针对 Neon EVM 上的 Tracing API 的文章。在 Twitter 上关注[@neonlabsorg](https://twitter.com/neonlabsorg)并打开通知，以免错过。

## 霓虹灯 dApp 竞赛

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*ILcZhG4Aaaam54yDudqQpQ.jpeg)

超过 15 个开发团队参加了将 dApp 与 Neon EVM 集成的竞赛。每个项目都根据以下五个标准进行评估：技术性、原创性、可用性（UX/UI/UD）、实用性和令人惊叹的因素。

祝贺获奖者：

🥇**一等奖**

参赛者：Madhur ( [@Chester_King__](https://twitter.com/Chester_King__) )

🥈**第二名**

参赛者：Thunderstorm — @ [anshumanagr73](https://twitter.com/anshumanagr73)、 @ [tunappaul](https://twitter.com/tunappaul)和[@minsankan](https://twitter.com/minusankan)

🥉**第三名**

参赛者：Maadhav Sharma

比赛的获胜者都将新的 MacBook 带回家。感谢所有参加霓虹灯竞赛并加入我们的人！

## 我们将参加的即将举行的活动

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*J1yRoocyQcwI51wpT8koRw.png)

我们正准备在整个六月参加一些激动人心的活动。看看下面的阵容并保存日期！在以下活动中加入 Neon Labs：

* [ETHPrague](https://ethprague.com/): 6月 7–12
* [ETHNewYork](https://nyc.ethglobal.co/): 6月 24–26

除了上述 6 月的活动外，一旦我们最终确定了日程安排，我们将分享夏季和秋季剩余时间的计划。

title: เหตุใดเราจึงต้องการโซเชียลกราฟแบบกระจายศูนย์?
body:
เมื่อเราลงทะเบียนบนแพลตฟอร์มโซเชียลมีเดียเป็นครั้งแรกนั้น มันแทบเหมือนจะเป็นสัญชาตญานไปแล้วที่จะต้องติดตามรายชื่อดาราที่แนะนำ หัวข้อที่คุณสนใจ และซิงค์รายชื่อติดต่อในโทรศัพท์หรือ Facebook สำหรับเพื่อนที่คุณอาจรู้จัก เราใช้คำแนะนำอัลกอริธึมเหล่านี้เสมือนเป็นสิ่งไม่มีค่าซะจนเราละเลยคำถามที่ว่า รายการพวกนี้สร้างขึ้นมาได้อย่างไร?

และแน่นอน เราตกลงที่จะยอมให้พวกเขาเข้าถึงข้อมูลส่วนตัว (เราเป็นใคร และ เราเกี่ยวเนื่องยังไงกับผู้อื่น) ในขณะที่เชื่อมต่อเราเข้ากับเพื่อนของเรา แพลตฟอร์มโซเชียลมีเดียเหล่านี้ก็ได้กำลังทำการ รวบรวม จัดเก็บ รักษา และทำเงินจากข้อมูลเหล่านี้ ข้อมูลของเรานี่แหละ สำหรับรายได้ที่มาจากการโฆษณา และนั่นแหละคือปัญหา ด้วยการพยายามหาทางออกให้เรื่องเหล่านี้ สตาร์ทอัพจำนวนหนึ่งสามารถใช้ประโยชน์จากเทคโนโลยีบล็อกเชนและระบบจัดเก็บแบบกระจายศูนย์ ไม่เพียงแต่สร้างแนวคิด แต่ตระหนักถึงมาตรฐานและแอปพลิเคชั่นของ Web3 อีกด้วย และ CyberConnect ก็คือหนึ่งในนั้น โปรโตคอลโซเชียลกราฟแบบกระจายศูนย์, CyberConnect ขับเคลื่อน Metaverse และ Dapps ด้วยการมีปฏิสัมพันธ์ของมนุษย์และการเชื่อมต่อที่ดีขึ้น

### แล้วคุณหมายถึงอะไรหละ ที่บอก “โซเชียลกราฟ”?

ข้อมูลสำคัญจำนวนมากที่เรามอบให้โซเชียลมีเดีย Web2 แบบรวมศูนย์คือความสัมพันธ์ทางสังคมของเรา เราเชื่อมโยงถึงใครและอย่างไร ด้วยจากการเชื่อมต่อรายบุคคลเหล่านี้แล้วนั้น ยักษ์ใหญ่ด้านโซเชียลมีเดีย เช่น Facebook สามารถสร้างโซเชียลกราฟขึ้นมาได้ (การทำแผนที่การเชื่อมต่อทั่วโลก) บางอย่างเราก็ไม่อาจสามารถที่จะติดตามได้ด้วยซ้ำ ยกตัวอย่างเช่น หลานสาวของพี่สะใภ้ของแม่ของจอห์นเป็นภรรยาเพื่อนของสามีของเจน หรือหลานคนโตของลุงของโดนัลด์กำลังออกเดทกับลูกสาวของเพื่อนร่วมงานของเดซี่ ฯลฯ (*งงมากบอกเลย*) คุณคงเข้าใจแหละ ในปัจจุบันยุคของ Web2, บริษัทต่างพากันใช้จ่ายไปอย่างมากเพื่อให้ได้มาซึ่งข้อมูลดังกล่าว และได้สร้างโซเชียลกราฟที่กระจัดกระจายของตัวเอง หรือก็คือ  - สวนที่มีกำแพง (หรือก็หมายถึงองค์กรที่มีอำนาจสูงสุดในการควบคุมข้อมูลนั้นๆในพื้นที่ของตัวเอง) ซึ่งก็น่าแดกดันยิ่งนัก ที่ถือว่าเป็นทรัพสินย์ที่มีค่าสูงสุดและเป็นแบบอย่างให้กับโมเดลธุรกิจที่ขับเคลื่อนด้วยโฆษณาของพวกบริษัทเหล่านี้

### แล้วมันมีปัญหายังไงหละ?

เยอะเลยแหละ การใช้ที่ไม่ปลอดภัยและไม่มีประสิทธิภาพของข้อมูล การปิดกั้นการสร้างรายได้ของเนื้อหา อุปสรรคที่สูงในการเข้ามาของนักพัฒนา ลิสต์พวกนี้ก็ยังมีต่อไปเรื่อยๆ เราจะกล่าวถึงสิ่งสำคัญโดยเฉพาะละกัน

สำหรับผู้ใช้งานและผู้บริโภค มันมีราคาของการเปลี่ยนไปใช้แพลตฟอร์มใหม่ที่สูงอยู่เสมอ ต้องสมัครบัญชีใหม่ กดติดตามเพื่อนอีกครั้ง หัวเสียเมื่อเพื่อนบางคนไม่กดติดตามกลับอีก ลองนึกดูว่าถ้ามีการเข้าสู่ระบบแบบสากล ซึ่งสิ่งนี้มีอยู่แล้ว ต้องขอบคุณ Ethereum address และภายในที่อยู่นั้นก็เก็บการเชื่อมต่อของคุณทั้งหมด ทุกๆครั้งที่คุณเข้าสู่ระบบเข้าไปในแพลตฟอร์มใหม่ๆด้วยบัญชีนี้ คุณสามารถดูรายชื่อเพื่อนและการติดตามจากแพลตฟอร์มอื่นๆทั้งหมดของคุณได้ ข้อมูลโซเชียลกราฟกลายเป็นสินทรัพย์ส่วนบุคคลและพกพาได้ที่คุณสามารถแพ็คของละออกไปได้เลย ทำลายกำแพงระหว่างแพลตฟอร์มและชุมชน ละสิ่งที่ดีกว่านั้นคือคุณได้เป็นเจ้าของข้อมูลส่วนบุคคลนั้นจริงๆเป็นครั้งแรก ได้ตัดสินใจว่าจะเอาอะไรเข้าไปเก็บและอะไรที่ดีสำหรับการแสดงผล

อุปสรรคที่ยิ่งใหญ่กว่านั้นได้ขวางทางนักพัฒนาไว้อยู่ พื้นที่โซเชียลมีเดียในปัจจุบันนี้ไม่เพียงเป็นแต่ศูนย์รวมอำนาจที่มากกว่าภาคการเงินเท่านั้น แต่อาจมีการแข่งแข่งขันที่มากกว่าเช่นกัน  
 สำหรับแต่ละแอปพลิเคชั่นที่พยายามจะสร้างผลลัพธ์ให้คนมองเห็นในพื้นที่แออัดนี้นั้น นักพัฒนาจำเป็นที่จะต้องสร้างโซเชียลกราฟใหม่ทุกครั้ง มันใช้ทั้งเวลา เงิน ความพยายาม และ ความโชคดีนิดนึง  
 อย่างไรก็ตาม จะเกิดอะไรขึ้นถ้ามีโซเชียลกราฟที่เป็น open-sourced ที่ปราศจากเจ้าของแบบรวมศูนย์และให้ทุกคนสามารถสร้างต่อจากตรงนี้ได้หละ? แอปพลิเคชั่นใดๆที่มีประโยชน์ใช้สอยและความบันเทิงที่แข่งแกร่งสามารถเบ่งบานได้อย่างง่ายๆเลย โดยไม่ต้องเปลืองทรัพยากรส่วนใหญ่ในการสร้างสิ่งที่มีอยู่แล้วขึ้นมาใหม่

### วิธีแก้ปัญหามีลักษณะเป็นยังไงหละ

CyberConnect คือโซเชียลกราฟโปรโตคอลแบบกระจายศูนย์ที่สนับสนุนโครงสร้างพื้นฐาน Web3 และเชิญชวนแอปพลิเคชั่นต่างๆให้มาสร้างขึ้นบนโครงสร้างพื้นฐานเหล่านี้ เราได้ทำการจัดเตรียม Module โซเชียลกราฟที่ได้มาตรฐานซึ่งเป็น open-sourced และเข้ากันได้กับหลายบล็อกเชน  
 เป็นโซเชียลกราฟที่มีชุมชนเป็นเจ้าของ และด้วยข้อมูลที่พกพาไปไหนก็ได้นำความเป็นไปได้ที่ไม่มีที่สิ้นสุดให้แก่ Web3 เกม, แอปส่งข้อความ, ฟีดข่าว, Metaverse, และอื่นๆอีกมากมาย ทำลายกำแพงระหว่างชุมชนและนิยามการปฏิสัมพันธ์ของมนุษย์ขึ้นมาใหม่ เพื่อให้ได้ลิ้มรสชาติ เราได้พัฒนา [CyberChat](https://www.cyberch.at/) เพื่อที่จะแสดงให้เห็นว่ากราฟข้อมูลถูกนำไปใช้ประโยชน์ได้อย่างไรอีกด้วย

title: Is METAVERSE a matter of FUTURE?
body:
***[Read it in portuguese](https://mirror.xyz/0x07121d1002B35011B4118751bf6Dca5AC282915E/GfMZyBdj1KKQDTfKU0CT3sqIDfa4MWxBbuK-LAFaNI8)***

The metaverse has really swept the market over the past year, with a wide variety of projects popping up with proposals to enter this market, especially after Mark Zuckerberg's announcement to reposition Facebook as META. But how will we ultimately be affected by these changes? How does the crypto market relate to all this news?

adsadsasa

![Facebook repositions the brand as a meta](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HA4jBdOlJXCTGTQa-oLKy.png?height=484&width=876)

A technology becomes truly relevant only as other concepts and technologies evolve. For example, in the early 1980s, the cell phone was a surreal invention, but with the advent of smartphones and the technology that accompanied that development, we can now send emails, access maps, send instant messages, and use a hundred different applications.

This evolutionary movement is no different with the Metaverse. Although it is a concept that has been around for a few decades, the revolution that cryptocurrencies and NFTS (non-fungible tokens) brought has allowed the concept of the Metaverse to evolve in a similar way that cell phones and smartphones did. The NFTS inserted into the metaverse represent an item, object, outfit, or anything that is unique. This allows people to securely buy, sell, or trade items, for example. In this context, cryptocurrencies can also be used for trading.

![Overview of the metaverse that is aligned with NFTs.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MrVf9GAYzrITxP1IiJK3W.png?height=790&width=1063)

It seems like a distant reality, but something similar is already happening in some games both in the cryptocurrency environment and in the traditional market. In 2021, several games were launched where interaction is done via NFTS. Games such as Axie infinity, Bombcrypto, Cryptocars, StartAtlas, and Sidus entered the market with the proposal to use NFTs as a means to interact with the games. Other platforms that do not use crypto technology but already have a "metaverse" and a system for trading items are the games Fortinite and Free Fire, platforms that could perfectly use the blockchain for greater user security.

![The StartAtlas game puts your foot in the metaverse](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4h0yt-SQHrlijlPX7s3OB.png?height=1080&width=1920)

Applications could extend beyond games and the gamer community. There's no predicting what will happen, but enthusiasts in this market say we will be able to use virtual reality to solve business-related problems, interact with communities in real-world ways, and use applications that expand opportunities in both the entertainment and business sectors. I am sure that over the next few decades, we will see the metaverse change the way people interact with the Internet. What about you? How far do you think the metaverse can go?

title: เหตุใดเราจึงต้องการโซเชียลกราฟแบบกระจายศูนย์?
body:
เมื่อเราลงทะเบียนบนแพลตฟอร์มโซเชียลมีเดียเป็นครั้งแรกนั้น มันแทบเหมือนจะเป็นสัญชาตญานไปแล้วที่จะต้องติดตามรายชื่อดาราที่แนะนำ หัวข้อที่คุณสนใจ และซิงค์รายชื่อติดต่อในโทรศัพท์หรือ Facebook สำหรับเพื่อนที่คุณอาจรู้จัก เราใช้คำแนะนำอัลกอริธึมเหล่านี้เสมือนเป็นสิ่งไม่มีค่าซะจนเราละเลยคำถามที่ว่า รายการพวกนี้สร้างขึ้นมาได้อย่างไร?

และแน่นอน เราตกลงที่จะยอมให้พวกเขาเข้าถึงข้อมูลส่วนตัว (เราเป็นใคร และ เราเกี่ยวเนื่องยังไงกับผู้อื่น) ในขณะที่เชื่อมต่อเราเข้ากับเพื่อนของเรา แพลตฟอร์มโซเชียลมีเดียเหล่านี้ก็ได้กำลังทำการ รวบรวม จัดเก็บ รักษา และทำเงินจากข้อมูลเหล่านี้ ข้อมูลของเรานี่แหละ สำหรับรายได้ที่มาจากการโฆษณา และนั่นแหละคือปัญหา ด้วยการพยายามหาทางออกให้เรื่องเหล่านี้ สตาร์ทอัพจำนวนหนึ่งสามารถใช้ประโยชน์จากเทคโนโลยีบล็อกเชนและระบบจัดเก็บแบบกระจายศูนย์ ไม่เพียงแต่สร้างแนวคิด แต่ตระหนักถึงมาตรฐานและแอปพลิเคชั่นของ Web3 อีกด้วย และ CyberConnect ก็คือหนึ่งในนั้น โปรโตคอลโซเชียลกราฟแบบกระจายศูนย์, CyberConnect ขับเคลื่อน Metaverse และ Dapps ด้วยการมีปฏิสัมพันธ์ของมนุษย์และการเชื่อมต่อที่ดีขึ้น

### แล้วคุณหมายถึงอะไรหละ ที่บอก “โซเชียลกราฟ”?

ข้อมูลสำคัญจำนวนมากที่เรามอบให้โซเชียลมีเดีย Web2 แบบรวมศูนย์คือความสัมพันธ์ทางสังคมของเรา เราเชื่อมโยงถึงใครและอย่างไร ด้วยจากการเชื่อมต่อรายบุคคลเหล่านี้แล้วนั้น ยักษ์ใหญ่ด้านโซเชียลมีเดีย เช่น Facebook สามารถสร้างโซเชียลกราฟขึ้นมาได้ (การทำแผนที่การเชื่อมต่อทั่วโลก) บางอย่างเราก็ไม่อาจสามารถที่จะติดตามได้ด้วยซ้ำ ยกตัวอย่างเช่น หลานสาวของพี่สะใภ้ของแม่ของจอห์นเป็นภรรยาเพื่อนของสามีของเจน หรือหลานคนโตของลุงของโดนัลด์กำลังออกเดทกับลูกสาวของเพื่อนร่วมงานของเดซี่ ฯลฯ (*งงมากบอกเลย*) คุณคงเข้าใจแหละ ในปัจจุบันยุคของ Web2, บริษัทต่างพากันใช้จ่ายไปอย่างมากเพื่อให้ได้มาซึ่งข้อมูลดังกล่าว และได้สร้างโซเชียลกราฟที่กระจัดกระจายของตัวเอง หรือก็คือ  - สวนที่มีกำแพง (หรือก็หมายถึงองค์กรที่มีอำนาจสูงสุดในการควบคุมข้อมูลนั้นๆในพื้นที่ของตัวเอง) ซึ่งก็น่าแดกดันยิ่งนัก ที่ถือว่าเป็นทรัพสินย์ที่มีค่าสูงสุดและเป็นแบบอย่างให้กับโมเดลธุรกิจที่ขับเคลื่อนด้วยโฆษณาของพวกบริษัทเหล่านี้

### แล้วมันมีปัญหายังไงหละ?

เยอะเลยแหละ การใช้ที่ไม่ปลอดภัยและไม่มีประสิทธิภาพของข้อมูล การปิดกั้นการสร้างรายได้ของเนื้อหา อุปสรรคที่สูงในการเข้ามาของนักพัฒนา ลิสต์พวกนี้ก็ยังมีต่อไปเรื่อยๆ เราจะกล่าวถึงสิ่งสำคัญโดยเฉพาะละกัน

สำหรับผู้ใช้งานและผู้บริโภค มันมีราคาของการเปลี่ยนไปใช้แพลตฟอร์มใหม่ที่สูงอยู่เสมอ ต้องสมัครบัญชีใหม่ กดติดตามเพื่อนอีกครั้ง หัวเสียเมื่อเพื่อนบางคนไม่กดติดตามกลับอีก ลองนึกดูว่าถ้ามีการเข้าสู่ระบบแบบสากล ซึ่งสิ่งนี้มีอยู่แล้ว ต้องขอบคุณ Ethereum address และภายในที่อยู่นั้นก็เก็บการเชื่อมต่อของคุณทั้งหมด ทุกๆครั้งที่คุณเข้าสู่ระบบเข้าไปในแพลตฟอร์มใหม่ๆด้วยบัญชีนี้ คุณสามารถดูรายชื่อเพื่อนและการติดตามจากแพลตฟอร์มอื่นๆทั้งหมดของคุณได้ ข้อมูลโซเชียลกราฟกลายเป็นสินทรัพย์ส่วนบุคคลและพกพาได้ที่คุณสามารถแพ็คของละออกไปได้เลย ทำลายกำแพงระหว่างแพลตฟอร์มและชุมชน ละสิ่งที่ดีกว่านั้นคือคุณได้เป็นเจ้าของข้อมูลส่วนบุคคลนั้นจริงๆเป็นครั้งแรก ได้ตัดสินใจว่าจะเอาอะไรเข้าไปเก็บและอะไรที่ดีสำหรับการแสดงผล

อุปสรรคที่ยิ่งใหญ่กว่านั้นได้ขวางทางนักพัฒนาไว้อยู่ พื้นที่โซเชียลมีเดียในปัจจุบันนี้ไม่เพียงเป็นแต่ศูนย์รวมอำนาจที่มากกว่าภาคการเงินเท่านั้น แต่อาจมีการแข่งแข่งขันที่มากกว่าเช่นกัน  
 สำหรับแต่ละแอปพลิเคชั่นที่พยายามจะสร้างผลลัพธ์ให้คนมองเห็นในพื้นที่แออัดนี้นั้น นักพัฒนาจำเป็นที่จะต้องสร้างโซเชียลกราฟใหม่ทุกครั้ง มันใช้ทั้งเวลา เงิน ความพยายาม และ ความโชคดีนิดนึง  
 อย่างไรก็ตาม จะเกิดอะไรขึ้นถ้ามีโซเชียลกราฟที่เป็น open-sourced ที่ปราศจากเจ้าของแบบรวมศูนย์และให้ทุกคนสามารถสร้างต่อจากตรงนี้ได้หละ? แอปพลิเคชั่นใดๆที่มีประโยชน์ใช้สอยและความบันเทิงที่แข่งแกร่งสามารถเบ่งบานได้อย่างง่ายๆเลย โดยไม่ต้องเปลืองทรัพยากรส่วนใหญ่ในการสร้างสิ่งที่มีอยู่แล้วขึ้นมาใหม่

### วิธีแก้ปัญหามีลักษณะเป็นยังไงหละ

CyberConnect คือโซเชียลกราฟโปรโตคอลแบบกระจายศูนย์ที่สนับสนุนโครงสร้างพื้นฐาน Web3 และเชิญชวนแอปพลิเคชั่นต่างๆให้มาสร้างขึ้นบนโครงสร้างพื้นฐานเหล่านี้ เราได้ทำการจัดเตรียม Module โซเชียลกราฟที่ได้มาตรฐานซึ่งเป็น open-sourced และเข้ากันได้กับหลายบล็อกเชน  
 เป็นโซเชียลกราฟที่มีชุมชนเป็นเจ้าของ และด้วยข้อมูลที่พกพาไปไหนก็ได้นำความเป็นไปได้ที่ไม่มีที่สิ้นสุดให้แก่ Web3 เกม, แอปส่งข้อความ, ฟีดข่าว, Metaverse, และอื่นๆอีกมากมาย ทำลายกำแพงระหว่างชุมชนและนิยามการปฏิสัมพันธ์ของมนุษย์ขึ้นมาใหม่ เพื่อให้ได้ลิ้มรสชาติ เราได้พัฒนา [CyberChat](https://www.cyberch.at/) เพื่อที่จะแสดงให้เห็นว่ากราฟข้อมูลถูกนำไปใช้ประโยชน์ได้อย่างไรอีกด้วย
